string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.

slidelink.displaytext: Three Principles of Universal Design for Learning

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: <Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white text" /> <Span Text="We will discuss the importance of creating inclusive and accessible learning environments for all students and the three Universal Design for Learning principles. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white text" /> <Span Text="Universal Design for Learning (UDL) is a teaching approach, rooted in cognitive neuroscience research, that strives to accommodate the needs and to remove unnecessary obstacles of the learning process for all students. UDL aims to create classrooms where every student can succeed by removing obstacles and giving everyone an equitable chance to learn. This can look like providing flexible learning environments with instruction presented in multiple ways, various options for learners to demonstrate their learning, and multiple ways for students to engage with information. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white text" /> <Span Text="What is essential for some, is good for all. This is a common quote that people reference in regards to UDL. The UDL framework provides a structure in lesson design that integrates inclusive strategies and options to support all learners in the classroom. Universal Design is grounded in the premise that learner variability is natural and normal. All learners have varied abilities, strengths, interests, perspectives, and experiences that can influence how they learn in any classroom. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white text" /> <Span Text="When developing a curriculum with UDL in mind, it is important to identify barriers in the curriculum or instructional process and work to minimize these obstacles for students. To create fully inclusive learning environments, we should consider how to provide students meaningful access to curriculum. UDL focuses on this proactive reduction of barriers, providing flexible pathways from the outset, and keeps in mind the variability of student learning throughout course design. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white text" /> <Span Text="There is an emphasis in UDL on the power of digital media as a means of providing a flexible curriculum for students to support multiple needs, abilities, and student interest in the same classroom. This is especially true in an online classroom, but can be applied to in-person classrooms as well. When designing an online learning course, some additional considerations must be taken into account. For example, when considering learner variability, you must not only consider the abilities and strengths of your learners, their preferences and interests, and their support needs, you must also consider their access to online environments and their ability to work independently at home. More examples of these extra considerations are provided in the modules other learning resources. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white text" /> <Span Text="Now lets dig into three major principles of UDL: Engagement, Representation, and Action and Expression. Each of these three principles has several guidelines that define how educators can provide options and support when designing their courses for students. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white text" /> <Span Text="Lets first discuss engagement. In order for students to feel engaged, they must feel connected to the learning in some way. This principle in UDL recognizes that every student learns differently, has unique identities, and finds connection in various ways. Not only can this change from student to student, but it can also change from day to day. That leads to the question: how can a teacher ensure that all students are engaged? Well, because there is no single best way to do this, it is vital we provide students with multiple ways to engage with the material. For example, lets say an online high school English teacher, Mrs. Reed, wants to increase engagement with reading. Instead of assigning the same book to all students, they might create a book club where students can choose a book from a list. Then, the teacher might also allow students to read and reflect independently or in groups. By providing these options, there is a greater likelihood for engagement. We will dive deeper into engagement strategies next week." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white text" /> <Span Text="Next, lets look at representation. Representation means providing information and context in multiple formats to cater to diverse learning preferences and accessibility needs. We know that students perceive and understand information in different ways. For example, students with sensory disabilities (such as blindness or deafness), learning disabilities (such as dyslexia), and those from different cultures will all approach learning differently. It is important that we respect these differences. But how do we make sure that there are multiple means of representation for students? Lets go back to our example of Mrs. Reed. Because Mrs. Reed knows that she has a lot of students with different perspectives. Instead of simply telling the students about their new online book club via written instructions, she will also make a video with captions and transcripts. She might also provide a visual infographic with descriptive alt-text for any images. By providing these multiple means, Mrs. Reed is removing barriers to accessing this information while providing them with multiple pathways to understanding." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white text" /> <Span Text="The last principle is action and expression, which focuses on giving students choices in how they demonstrate their understanding of the material. Students have different ways to approach learning, tasks, and showing what they know. For example, some students might prefer writing over speaking. Some might prefer planning what they want to say while others might enjoy an impromptu nature. Expressing thoughts and actions takes a lot of strategy, patience, and organization, which varies from student to student. Lets go back to Mrs. Reed and see how she might design multiple means for action and expression with her online book club. Instead of assessing students through a traditional book report, she allows students to choose how they will share their learning. Some options she provides include a written report, video, podcast, presentation, or art project. This design allows for the wide variability of students strengths and experiences while still requiring all students to demonstrate mastery of the content. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white text" /> <Span Text="In this video, you were introduced to the importance of accessibility in student success in an online environment and the three principles of Universal Design for Learning. The other videos, texts, graphics, and activities included in this module will dive more deeply into some of these UDL principles and how you can apply these in your classroom. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>
